overview_of_class:
This course will introduce students to methods used in psychological research. Through readings, lectures, discussion, and hands-on activities (specifically the handling of a statistics program used for data collection and analyses), students will learn about the scientific approach to research designs and about the analysis and interpretation of data. They will participate in novel research projects and will write a report on each in the style used by research psychologists.

Primary goals are for students to learn (1) testing hypotheses, including data collection and statistical analyses, (2) writing effectively about research plans and findings, and (3) critically evaluating psychological research done by other people.
name: Research Methods in Psychology
title: WCAS PSYCH 205-0-20 Research Methods in Psychology

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
This course will introduce students to methods used in psychological research. Through readings, lectures, discussion, and hands-on activities (specifically the handling of a statistics program used for data collection and analyses), students will learn about the scientific approach to research designs and about the analysis and interpretation of data. They will participate in novel research projects and will write a report on each in the style used by research psychologists.

Primary goals are for students to learn (1) testing hypotheses, including data collection and statistical analyses, (2) writing effectively about research plans and findings, and (3) critically evaluating psychological research done by other people.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Prerequisite: Psychology 201 or equivalent

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value:
Evaluation is based on completion of 3 APA style research reports, along with two essay exams and several
short papers.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
University of Minnesota Libraries (2016). Research Methods in Psychology. Available for free download at https://open.umn.edu/opentextbooks/BookDetail.aspx?bookId=75

Also, additional readings will be posted on Canvas

subject: PSYCH

overview_of_class: This course provides an introduction to designing, conducting, evaluating, and presenting psychological research. Among the topics to be covered are: experimental and non-experimental research; statistical analyses; writing psychological reports; ethics in research; and utilizing library resources. Students will collect and analyze data for three research projects during the quarter, and write a report on each in the style used by research psychologists.
name: Research Methods in Psychology
title: WCAS PSYCH 205-0-21 Research Methods in Psychology

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course provides an introduction to designing, conducting, evaluating, and presenting psychological research. Among the topics to be covered are: experimental and non-experimental research; statistical analyses; writing psychological reports; ethics in research; and utilizing library resources. Students will collect and analyze data for three research projects during the quarter, and write a report on each in the style used by research psychologists.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Students must be Psychology majors and must have taken Psychology 201 (or equivalent coursework).

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
At the end of the course you should be able to:
? Demonstrate proficiency with regard to the terminology and concepts involved in psychological research, especially with regard to experimentation
? Obtain research articles relevant to a psychological topic via the online databases (PsycINFO, PsycARTICLES, Google Scholar), and synthesize this research
? Formulate hypotheses and design research to test these hypotheses
? Effectively communicate the results of your own psychological research by writing clear, persuasive, appropriately formatted APA-style research reports
? Critically evaluate research results reported by others

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value:
Case studies,?
Class participation,?
Discussion,?
Fieldwork,?
Films/Videos,?
Group work,?
Weekly Lectures,
Presentations,?
Readings,?
Research project,?
Writing assignments

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value:
Research and Written Research Reports,
Peer Evaluation,
Exams,
Short writing Assignments,
Class attendance/participation,
Final Project

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Cozby, P.C., & Bates, S.C. (2012). Methods in behavioral research (11th ed.). New York: McGraw Hill. ISBN: 978-0-07-803515-9.

Stanovich, K.E. (2013). How to think straight about psychology (10th ed.). New York: Pearson. ISBN: 978-0-205-91412-8.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Suggested)
descriptions.value:
American Psychological Association. (2010). Publication manual of the American Psychological Association (6th ed.). Mountain View, CA: Mayfield Publishing Company. ISBN: 978-1-433-80561-5

Additional readings included on the syllabus will either be distributed in class or posted on Canvas throughout the quarter.

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: Students must be Psychology majors and have taken Psychology 201 (or equivalent coursework).

class_attributes:
Attendance at 1st class mandatory

Prerequisites apply, see description
subject: PSYCH

overview_of_class:
Psychology is the science of behavior and mind. As with any science, psychology begins with scientific questions that are translated into hypotheses, which are then tested with various research methods to provide evidence for or against a theory. Whether you are conducting a survey to test how extraversion relates to political affiliation or a neuroimaging experiment to test what neural pathways are involved in memory recall, it is important that your study be scientifically sound in its design and methodology. Without rigorously scientific research methods, we cannot make strong conclusions about data or anything in psychology, and much of what we know about our behaviors, thoughts, attitudes, and development would fall apart. Thus, this course is extremely important, because it will help you to critically and scientifically think about, develop, and actually test ideas in psychology.

In this course, we will take a hands-on approach to evaluating, designing, conducting, and presenting psychological research. We will learn how to critically read and write about psychology, translate research questions into testable hypotheses, design empirical studies to test those hypotheses, conduct the appropriate statistical analyses on the data collected, and write research papers that detail the results in the style used by research psychologists. By the end, you will have experience with every part of the research process and completed your own psychological studies as part of a group. Because this course is not content specific, the knowledge and skills that you learn can be applied to courses and research in all areas of psychology, and even all areas of science.
name: Research Methods in Psychology
title: WCAS PSYCH 205-0-22 Research Methods in Psychology

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Psychology is the science of behavior and mind. As with any science, psychology begins with scientific questions that are translated into hypotheses, which are then tested with various research methods to provide evidence for or against a theory. Whether you are conducting a survey to test how extraversion relates to political affiliation or a neuroimaging experiment to test what neural pathways are involved in memory recall, it is important that your study be scientifically sound in its design and methodology. Without rigorously scientific research methods, we cannot make strong conclusions about data or anything in psychology, and much of what we know about our behaviors, thoughts, attitudes, and development would fall apart. Thus, this course is extremely important, because it will help you to critically and scientifically think about, develop, and actually test ideas in psychology.

In this course, we will take a hands-on approach to evaluating, designing, conducting, and presenting psychological research. We will learn how to critically read and write about psychology, translate research questions into testable hypotheses, design empirical studies to test those hypotheses, conduct the appropriate statistical analyses on the data collected, and write research papers that detail the results in the style used by research psychologists. By the end, you will have experience with every part of the research process and completed your own psychological studies as part of a group. Because this course is not content specific, the knowledge and skills that you learn can be applied to courses and research in all areas of psychology, and even all areas of science.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Prerequisite: Psychology 201 or equivalent

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Grades will be based on three APA-style research reports, two short critiques, an exam, and participation (including group working sessions and other activities).

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Text: Cozby, P. C., & Bates, S. C. (2012). Methods in behavioral research (11th ed.). New York: McGraw Hill. ISBN: 9780078035159. [Note that this is one edition prior to the most current edition, which hopefully will help with cost.]
Additional Readings: Available on the course website (links in the syllabus)

class_attributes:
Attendance at 1st class mandatory

Prerequisites apply, see description
subject: PSYCH

overview_of_class:
This course will introduce students to research methods in psychology. Through lecture and lab sections,
students will learn about both research design and data analysis. This course will include several group research projects as well as individual written assignments. Primary goals for the course include (1) improvement of scientific writing, (2) development of skills in research design (experimental and nonexperimental), (3) learning basics of data analysis (using a statistical software package), and (4) development of critical thinking skills. By the end of the class students should be better able to conduct their own research and critically interpret the results of others' research.
name: Research Methods in Psychology
title: WCAS PSYCH 205-0-23 Research Methods in Psychology

descriptions.value:

Primary goals for the course include (1) improvement of scientific writing, (2) development of skills in research design (experimental and nonexperimental), (3) learning basics of data analysis (using a statistical software package), and (4) development of critical thinking skills. By the end of the class students should be better able to conduct their own research and critically interpret the results of others' research.
